publication.title: A first step toward detecting SSH identity theft in HPC cluster environments: discriminating masqueraders based on command behavior
publication.jconf: Cluster Computing and the Grid
publication.keyword: Feature Construction;High Performance;High Performance Computer;Identity Theft;Support Vector Machine;high per formance computing;information re trieval;Multi User;
publication.abstract: Recent attacks enabled by stolen authentication pass- words and keys have allowed intruders to masquerade as legitimate users on high performance computing clusters. With the motivation of detecting masqueraders on clus- ters, this work seeks to discriminate different types of use rs based on their command behavior - in particular, user com- mand behavior on a multi-user public machine versus

publication.title: Efficient Mining of Recurrent Rules from a Sequence Database
publication.jconf: Database Systems for Advanced Applications
publication.keyword: Case Study;Linear Temporal Logic;Program Specification;Program Verification;Software Specification;
publication.abstract: We study a novel problem of mining significant recurrent rules from a sequence database. Recurrent rules have the form "when- ever a series of precedent events occurs, eventually a series of consequent events occurs". Recurrent rules are intuitive and characterize behaviors in many domains. An example is in the domain of software specifications, in which the rules capture a family

publication.title: How Bayesians Debug
publication.jconf: IEEE International Conference on Data Mining
publication.keyword: Data Mining;Fault Analysis;Fault Localization;Fault Location;Software Engineering;
publication.abstract: Manual debugging is expensive. And the high cost has motivated extensive research on automated fault lo- calization in both software engineering and data mining communities. Fault localization aims at automatically locating likely fault locations, and hence assists manual debugging. A number of fault localization algorithms have been developed in recent years, which prove effec- tive when multiple failing and passing

publication.title: Efficient SIP-Specific Event Notification
publication.jconf: International Conference on Networking
publication.abstract: By Session Initiation Protocol (SIP), the entities in the network can subscribe to the resource or the call state for various resources or calls in the network. Those entities (or entities acting on their behalf) can send notifications when those states change. We propose a new approach to subscribe the information of part resources of the user's re- source list.

publication.title: Indexing Noncrashing Failures: A Dynamic Program Slicing-Based Approach
publication.jconf: International Conference on Software Maintenance
publication.keyword: Case Study;Crash Failure;Dynamic Program Slicing;Dynamic Slicing;Indexation;Software Systems;
publication.abstract: Recent software systems usually feature an automated failure reporting component, with which a huge number of failures are collected from software end-users. With a proper support of failure indexing, which identifies failures due to the same fault, the collected failure data can help de- velopers prioritize failure diagnosis, among other utilities of the failure data. publication.title: Mining past-time temporal rules from execution traces
publication.jconf: International Symposium on Software Testing and Analysis
publication.keyword: Application Server;Data Mining;Dynamic Analysis;Program Understanding;Rule Based;
publication.abstract: Specification mining is a process of extracting specifications, often from program execution traces. These specifications can in turn be used to aid program understanding, monitoring and verification. There are a number of dynamic-analysis-based specification min- ing tools in the literature, however none so far extract past time tem- poral expressions in the form of rules stating: "whenever a series of

publication.title: GPLAG: detection of software plagiarism by program dependence graph analysis
publication.jconf: Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining
publication.keyword: Control Dependence;Graph Mining;Graphical Representation;Open Source;Plagiarism Detection;Program Dependence Graph;Search Space;Lines of Code;
publication.abstract: Along with the blossom of open source projects comes the convenience for software plagiarism. A company, if less self-disciplined, may be tempted to plagiarize some open source projects for its own products. Although current pla- giarism detection tools appear sufficient for academic use, they are nevertheless short for fighting against serious pla- giarists. For example, disguises like statement reordering and

publication.title: BBM: bayesian browsing model from petabyte-scale data
publication.jconf: Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining
publication.abstract: Given a quarter of petabyte click log data, how can we esti- mate the relevance of each URL for a given query? In this paper, we propose the Bayesian Browsing Model (BBM), a new modeling technique with following advantages: (a) it does exact inference; (b) it is single-pass and parallelizable; (c) it is effective. We present two sets of experiments

publication.title: Efficient mining of iterative patterns for software specification discovery
publication.jconf: Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining
publication.keyword: Case Study;Pattern Mining;Program Comprehension;Sequential Pattern;Software Development;Software Evolution;Software Specification;Temporal Pattern;
publication.abstract: Studies have shown that program comprehension takes up to 45% of software development costs. Such high costs are caused by the lack-of documented speciflcation and further aggravated by the phenomenon of software evolution. There is a need for automatic tools to extract speciflcations to aid program comprehension. In this paper, a novel technique to e-ciently mine common software temporal patterns

publication.title: Step-by-Step Regression: A More Efficient Alternative for Polynomial Multiple Linear Regression in Stream Cube
publication.jconf: Pacific-Asia Conference on Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining
publication.keyword: Curve Fitting;Data Stream;Data Stream Management System;Generation Time;Management System;Modeling Tool;Multiple Linear Regression;Front End;Real Time;
publication.abstract: Facing tremendous and potentially infinite stream data, it is impossible to record them entirely. Thus synopses are required to be generated timely to capture the underlying model for stream management systems. Traditionally, curve fitting through Multiple Linear Regression (MLR) is a powerful and efficient modeling tool. In order to further accelerate its processing efficiency, we propose Step-by-step Regression (SR) as

publication.title: Mining Control Flow Abnormality for Logic Error Isolation
publication.jconf: SIAM International Conference on Data Mining
publication.abstract: Analyzing the executions of a buggy program is essen- tially a data mining process: Tracing the data generated during program executions may disclose important pat- terns and outliers that could eventually reveal the lo- cation of software errors. In this paper, we investigate program logic errors, which rarely incur memory ac- cess violations but generate incorrect outputs. We show that

publication.authors: xifeng yan,hwanjo yu,jiawei han,philip s. yu
publication.jconf: SIAM International Conference on Data Mining
publication.abstract: Analyzing the executions of a buggy software program is es- sentially a data mining process. Although many interesting methods have been developed to trace crashing bugs (such as memory violation and core dumps), it is still difficult to analyze noncrashing bugs (such as logical errors). In this paper, we develop a novel method to classify the structured traces of program

publication.title: Failure proximity: a fault localization-based approach
publication.keyword: Case Study;Fault Diagnosis;Fault Localization;Fault Location;Software Systems;Statistical Debugging;
publication.abstract: Recent software systems usually feature an automated fail- ure reporting system, with which a huge number of failing traces are collected every day. In order to prioritize fault diagnosis, failing traces due to the same fault are expected to be grouped together. Previous methods, by hypothesiz- ing that similar failing traces imply the same fault, cluster failing traces based on

publication.title: SOBER: statistical model-based bug localization
publication.authors: xifeng yan,long fei,jiawei han,samuel p. midkiff
publication.keyword: It Evaluation;Model Evaluation;Prior Knowledge;Statistical Debugging;Statistical Model;
publication.abstract: Automated localization of software bugs is one of the essential issues in debugging aids. Previous studies indicated that the evaluation history of program predicates may disclose important clues about underlying bugs. In this paper, we propose a new statistical model-based approach, called SOBER, which localizes software bugs without any prior knowledge of program semantics. Unlike existing approaches that select predicates

publication.abstract: Many tasks that leverage web search users' implicit feed- back rely on a proper and unbiased interpretation of user clicks. Previous eye-tracking experiments and studies on explaining position-bias of user clicks provide a spectrum of hypotheses and models on how an average user examines and possibly clicks web documents returned by a search en- gine with respect to the submitted

publication.jconf: World Wide Web Conference Series
publication.keyword: bayesian framework;bayesian model;Experimental Study;Gold Mining;Log Analysis;Search Engine;Web Documents;Web Search;
publication.abstract: Given a terabyte click log, can we build an efficient and ef- fective click model? It is commonly believed that web search click logs are a gold mine for search business, because they reflect users' preference over web documents presented by the search engine. Click models provide a principled ap- proach to inferring user-perceived relevance of web docu- ments, which

publication.abstract: Mining subtopics from weblogs and analyzing their spatiotemporal patterns have applications in multiple domains. publication.abstract: SUMMARY Software evolution incurs difficulties in program comprehension and software verification, and hence it increases the cost of software maintenance. In this study, we propose a novel technique to mine from program execution traces a sound and complete set of statistically significant temporal rules of arbitrary lengths. publication.abstract: Web applications have become complex and crucial in many fields.
